title-group.article-title: Solitary Fibrous Tumor of the Vagina
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report With Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: 1Institut de Pathologie et Génétique (IPG), Gosselies, Belgium

author-notes.corresp: Ngendahayo Placide, Institut de Pathologie et Génétique (IPG), 25 Avenue Georges Lemaître, Gosselies 6041, Belgium Email: placide.ngendahayo@ipg.be

abstract.p: Solitary fibrous tumor, initially described in the pleura, is now known to occur in various extrathoracic sites. However, its occurrence in the female genital tract, especially the vagina, is extremely rare. The authors report here a case of a well-circumscribed vaginal spindle cell nodule in a 48-year-old woman with features consistent with solitary fibrous tumor. The diagnosis was established histologically by the varying pattern with hypocellular fibrous areas alternating with hypercellular areas and hemangiopericytoma-like areas and, immunohistochemically by the strong positive reaction for CD34 and Bcl2 with a negative reaction for all other spindle cell and epithelial markers. The differential diagnosis is discussed and a review of the literature is presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Solitary fibrous tumor (SFT), initially described by Klemperer and Rabin1 as a pleural-based spindle cell neoplasm, has been subsequently reported in various extrathoracic sites. Nevertheless, its occurrence in the female genital tract, especially the vagina, is extremely rare and very few cases have been reported.2-4 The tumors are described as having a patternless pattern of proliferation of bland spindle cells in a vascular and collagenized stroma, and they typically show immunoreactivity for CD34 as well as Bcl2 and, in some cases, for CD99.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 48-year-old woman, with a previous history of benign endometrial glandular polyp, was admitted to the hospital because of a “sensation of mass” in the vagina. The examination revealed a firm nodule in the vagina. No other abnormality was found. The nodule was resected and the patient is free of disease 6 years after the excision.

sec.title: Pathological Findings
sec.p: The specimen consisted of a 18 × 10 × 10 mm, well-delineated, gray-whitish, and firm nodule. Microscopically, the nodule was well circumscribed and displayed a varying pattern. Hypocellular fibrous areas alternated with hypercellular areas (Figures 1 and 2) and a scattering of hemangiopericytoma-like areas (Figure 3). The nuclei were ovoid or elongated, with a fine chromatin and inconspicuous nuclei.

caption.p: Low power view: well delineated nodule with alternating hypocellular and hypercellular areas

sec.p: The tumor cells were strongly positive for CD34 (Figure 4) and Bcl2 (Figure 5) and negative for cytokeratin AE1/3, CAM5.2, EMA, SMA, S-100 protein, desmin, and CD99.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: SFTs, initially described in the pleura,1 are now known to occur in other sites and have been described under various names such as fibrous mesothelioma, submesothelial fibroma, and localized fibrous tumor.

SFTs have now been recognized in various extrathoracic sites such as liver,5 kidney,6 prostate,7 skin,8,9 parotid gland,10 thyroid gland,11 urinary bladder,12 nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses,13 tongue,14 meninges,15 breast,16 mediastinum,17 sclera,18 pancreas,19 soft tissues,20 uterus,21 buccal mucosa,22 retroperitoneum,23 oral cavity,24 orbit,25 and adrenal gland.26
Although described in such various sites, its occurrence in the vagina is extremely rare. Our case appears, to our knowledge, to be the fourth documented case of SFT occurring in the vagina.

The microscopic feature of SFT is described as “patternless” with a combination of growth patterns, including storiform (dermatofibroma-like), herring-bone, neural with wavy nuclei, or arborizing (hemangiopericytoma-like). SFTs consistently show strong reactivity for CD3425,27 and Bcl2,28 and reactivity for CD99 has also been reported.29

The differential diagnosis of SFT includes neurofibroma, leyomyoma, dermatofibroma, and above all, myofibroblastoma and the so-called spindle cell epithelioma or mixed tumor of the vagina. The latter can be purely mesenchymal and histologically very similar to SFT.30 It is also positive for CD34, Bcl2, and CD99 as is SFT.31,32 However, spindle cell epithelioma is strongly positive for epihelial30-32 and smooth muscle31 markers, whereas SFT is consistently negative for those markers.

Myofibroblastoma33,34 has a multipatterned architecture that may mimic SFT. However, myofibroblastoma of the lower genital tract is positive for desmin, SMA, and estrogen and progesterone receptors.33

The vast majority of SFTs are benign and local excision is curative in most cases. However, rare atypical and malignant forms have been reported in thoracic and extrathoracic localizations.35 These forms are characterized by high cellularity, increased mitotic activity, nuclear pleomorphism, and necrosis and show recurrence and metastasis.35
Although SFT is rare in the female genital tract, it should be always considered in the differential diagnosis of lesions showing fibroblastic, muscular, neural, and myofibroblastic differentiation.
